participants.participant: Corrado Passera, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning. Good afternoon for some of you. Thank you for joining us today. We're presenting our 2007 results and a number of ideas we have in mind.

Difficult times on the market, for sure. But I'm talking on behalf also of my top people in the team that manages with me Intesa Sanpaolo. We are confident that our business is in very good share and that is the reason why we confer our financial targets and our goals for the Business Plan 2006 and 2009. I will obviously elaborate on all the details. But let me just give you my feeling about this confidence on our results.

The 2007 results taking apart the trading revenues are well in line with our target for the year. The integration process that is a very complex one has been implemented in a very successful way. We believe that we are ahead of schedule and that was the main challenge in 2007.

And during these 15 months, the Bank has been able to build a number of engines, the number of drivers that will create growth and we will reach speed during 2008, full speed during 2008. So first point, we confirm our objectives.

Second point, during 2007 we had, as you know, a number of very significant capital gains. We decided to use part of them to make our P&L and our balance sheet stronger in the future, what I mean. For example, we had a number of legal situations that might have lasted for years and would have cost a lot in terms of legal cost and also in terms of mediatic effects. So we decided to close them.

Parmalat is the most well known. It's something that was expensive, because more than 100 million had to be added to what we had already provisioning for. But that's closed. Another way we used the – some of our capital gains was a very prudent evaluation of all our shareholdings, of all our assets, and that's the reason why we had decided to impair the value of Nextra, that was both the occasion of the agreement with Crédit Agricole and that accounts for 260 million on the fourth quarter results and then on the year results.

In the fourth quarter, we have other two effects that are negative, if we look at them immediately, but might be another – other good reasons for making our results stronger in the future. One is the fiscal effect of the improvement of the tax rate. Because of the reduction of the tax rate this year, we had to pay almost 380 – almost 400 million because the future fiscal benefits we had in our accounts had to be corrected with the new lower tax rate. And so in the fourth quarter of this year, we have a total unexpected effect of 385 million.

And the last effect is trading profits. Trading profits in the fourth quarter were negative, 65 million negative. But given the situation, we consider it to be a very reasonable result. That comes from a number of components. The main one has to do with the structured credit products, where we took devaluations, write-downs non-realized losses, something that might come back in the future for 360 million.

So if you take these four elements, the Parmalat and the other legal case settlement, the Nextra impairment, the fiscal changes, the fiscal – the tax rate charges and the devaluation, they're very prudent. I will talk about it because we will give total transparency to that. So they're very prudent devaluation of the structured credit products portfolio. I mean, you get more or less to 1 billion. So we used – let me use this word that is not right, but gives the feeling – part of our capital gains for these four elements. We then got to €7,250 million worth of net income and we confirm the dividend, both the ordinary dividend and the extraordinary dividend.

What else before we start with the figures. The situation on the market is difficult. I don't have to tell you why, and a lot of banks have been and will be affected by this situation. We strongly believe that our bank will be much less affected than others. First of all, because of our strong liquidity position, we are structurally imbalanced. Our customer loans are financed by customer deposits. So we don't have to rely on external markets to fund our industrial activity, that's a very safe and comfortable position.

The second is the business – our business model. We are simple. We have four businesses. The retail, the Banca dei Territori one, the Corporate & Investment Banking one, the Public Finance one and then we have our International Subsidiary Division. Four businesses, very clear, very business. The largest part of our revenues come from retail, more than 80%, to a large extent, to a certain extent foreseeable. I mean, something that you can count on.

The Corporate & Investment Banking activity is strong, is 16 or 18% of our portfolio. But very much basic things, very strong relationships with long-term customers; a number of activities where we are leaders in our market, no finance kind of things. So the business model is simple and to a certain extent less effected by market turmoils. The liquidity, market model, and the third, is the very prudent evaluation and devaluations we have made of our proprietary portfolio. We will go through that, because we will give you all the details and – but comfortable position also in that respect. In such a situation, a bank like ours might have and might enjoy some opportunity, some good opportunity in the future.

As you know, we have a number of very focused acquisitions in mind to strengthen our businesses. Nothing on the table today, but the Business Plan provided for some acquisitions in Eastern Europe and we got the right thing in Ukraine. We want to reinforce asset management, but we decided not to do it now. Let's wait for the market to settle down. So we will be able to do that because of liquidity and equity stability.

Second, we might have some more opportunity because of interesting assets that we might find on the market. I'm not talking about distressed assets. We are not going to buy any kind of distressed asset. But we might find in the next month good assets at distressed value, at distressed prices, so who knows, maybe. For sure, we will finance new acquisitions with divestment, and we have found a number of non-core activities in our portfolio that if needed are – can balance our investment. So that's another message I wanted to convey at the beginning.

Last point is about transparency. We've always been transparent; we will always be transparent. But we decided to go a step further. According to what Pillar 3 under Basle 2 provides for and according to what a number of people believe, we too believe. So we have to make a further effort in terms of transparency to help the market get out of the situation. We all have to be committed to recreate trust on the market, and transparency is a key element for building trust and confidence. So we are going to give you all the details of our, for example, credit structured products, nothing to hide. And for each component we will give you what it is, what's the collateral, and then how much we evaluated the item. So you have to know what we know, and I'm sure you will agree with us on the fact that we have been very prudent in evaluating these assets.

So now I will go through the usual presentation and then we will have all the questions. The first two pages are the methodological pages; the parameters, the consolidation areas. I mean, I will not go through them. You will get these details when you want.

This is a summary of the summary, and of the points that I made. The recurring operating performance is better than what we had in our target. What I mean by recurring is whatever is not trading, keeping up our trading. That as I said was a negative in the fourth quarter. But the rest, the industrial activity is well in line with our business target.

Second is the point I made about the asset valuation, very prudent, that will help us in standing the situation also in 2008. Third point about 2007, we had a commitment to give €5 billion worth of dividend, 2 billion of them extraordinary dividend, we confirm it. For 2008, we are helped by the valuation we made in 2007 and these are the two main points. We will complete the integration that is ahead of schedule, I will give you some evidence of it. And we will complete the development of drivers for growth. I mean, they have to be at full speed by the end of the year in order to reach the accrued speed we had in mind for 2009.

We confirm the ordinary dividends, the dividends we committed for in the Business Plan for 2008, but I will comment on dividends a little bit later. And same thing for 2009. Net income of the Business Plan was 7 billion. Dividends were 4.5, we confirm them. And the only change we made is the 6%. On the results of 2009, if everything has gone according to plans, we will distribute to shareholders whatever is in excess of 6%. In the Business Plan we had 6.5%, but we believe that a company that at that point is a company capable to create €7 billion worth of net profits every year and has gone through the complete restructuring of the Group, can afford this kind of Core Tier 1 ratio and that's the only change versus the Business Plan.

Results of the year; growth, that is the main point. You remember we have a four pillar strategy; sustainable growth, very strict cost control, very strict risk control and investment. Now, we added one point to the four pillar strategy of the Group. We added liquidity, very strong attention to liquidity. So growth is the first of four elements that have become five.

Growth, recurring growth is here. We are in – almost in line with the 7%, but the 7% is what we have to have on average. The first year was the year of the restructuring, of the firings of the people, of the transfer of the people. So we are very happy about this 5.5. New – 200,000 new customers, a good value that has to be exploited in the future.

Costs better than what we had in mind. You will see 3.7. The real comparison is 1.1, because we had an extraordinary benefit from the change in the TFR legislation. But minus 1.1 before the merger synergies, because we will start getting the synergies in 2008 and 2009, is a good performance. The combination of growth and cost control bring us to 15% growth in operating, recurring margin that is more than in line with our Business Plan target.

Cost of credit, in line. You might remember that we have 40% – 40 basis point as our target; is 41, but actually is 38. Because in the first quarter we decided to change a number of mortgage contracts to make our marketing efforts easier. So the real recurring is 38. So in line with the 40 basis points we had in the Business Plan.

The quality of our assets, so far in line. No real evidence of a change of or a decrease in the quality. The non-performing loans down total amount, absolute amounts down versus the end of 2006. Very strong generic reserve is the reserve we have on performing loans, 2.2 billion. And then as I said before, we closed a number of litigations, a number of legal situations that might have been annoying. Liquidity is what I said. I don't want to repeat.

Dividend; dividends exactly what we said, almost 5 billion in terms of yield on – I don't know which price, some days ago price is between 9 and 10%. Future dividends, we confirm all the dividends – we are at page eight, I am saying that for the people that are just listening to us and not watching the presentation, sorry, I haven't done it before. Page eight, our future dividends, we confirm all the dividends that we had in the Business Plan. Then we have two question marks because we cannot say or not commit for extraordinary dividends in 2009, not foreseen in the Plan by the way, or in 2010. But as I said before, we will distribute extra dividends should the Group have a Core Tier 1 in excess of 6%, not 6.5 as previously provided for.

Page 9 and page 10. I don't want to take you through all these figures, but you will find these pages useful to make the comparison possible, because there are so many exceptional items. The merger cost, amortization, the asset available for sale, divestment, the Parmalat rather than other legal cases, the trading profits. So here you see what I mentioned before. In terms of tax rate, in terms of tax charges, we have almost 400 million extra charge. So we are paying 39% that is far from being our running rate.

Actually, we will have – thanks to the new regulations, we will have from now on no more than 30, that is less than what the Business Plan provided for, 33 becomes 30. While in 2008 we pay this extra charge. So I will not go through that, but you have to keep in mind in comparing the results that items like the extra impairment of the tax rate or the Parmalat or the trading profits, are items that make the comparisons very difficult.

Same thing for the last quarter where we have all the effect of most of these items. So if you compare the two quarters, the fourth 2007 is better than 2006. While if you take at face value the figures, you are a bit intrigued.

Summary, we said some of these figures already. In terms of operating income, plus 5.5%; operating costs, minus 1%; cost/income down to 51; operating margin up 15; pre-tax income up 15%; net income – okay, but we have all the capital gains here.

Liquidity, as I said before, the direct customer deposits, the structural deposits of the Bank are stronger than the loans to customers. So this balance, this structural balance between customer loans and customer deposits make our liquidity situation rather comfortable.

Here you've all the details of the P&L. I don't repeat what I've already said before. These two arrows are to – but we will comment on each line. For sure the 11% growth in net interest income is a good figure. And we see these figures continuing also in 2008 and 2009 because of the performance in terms of volume. I will tell you when we get to that point.
Let's keep going. The portfolio, as I said, 82% comes from retail and private, and the rest is also very sound. But it's a point I already made.

In net interest income, 11% year-on-year, that figure comes from page 15. I keep forgetting to give the page. Page 15, 11% growth in interest income. We have volumes going up more or less on average 10%, but different growth rates. SMEs have to be kept under control if we want to keep the quality of our loan portfolio at the level where we are. We have to be prudent. But volumes 10%, markups well defended; markdowns, obviously, widening because of what happened in terms of market yields during 2007. The last quarter was the best quarter ever recorded in our accounts.

Commissions, commissions down as foreseen a bit lower than expected, but we have already commented this trend. The reason why we are down 2% is to a certain extent because of the physiological effect of the merger, customers move between the two product offers in order to get the best prices. And we are – for example, we are concentrating our current accounts in Zerotondo, that is zero commissions, so we had during the year a number of customers moving there, rationally moving in that direction and so we lost probably around of 80, 90 million.

The big lack of commissions was with asset management products. It's a market problem. It's a problem about the expectations of people, but it's also a problem of ours that we have to fix. I will elaborate a little. Because asset management is probably the largest opportunity area for us, all the other commissions have performed very well. And what is nice about the last quarter, the reduction stopped and this figure is there despite the fact that we reduced by 50% the front fee income, because, as we said in a number of occasions, we are reducing in a significant way that component of our revenues.

Trading profit, trading profit down from 1.8 billion to 1 billion, reasonable – I don't know if it is reasonable, but that's the case. And this is the 64 loss we suffered from in the last quarter. This 64 million loss come mainly from the decisions we have taken in terms of evaluation of our structured product portfolio. We will go through that in – very much in detail. But the 360 million worth of devaluations markdowns to be made according to mark-to-market values brought to minus 64 the quarterly results.

Let's look at the structured credit product portfolio. In the next pages, you will get the summary. Then in the appendices, you will get some detail and then there is a document with the press release that give all the possible details. We have subdivided the portfolio into three pieces; the subprime, the contagion area, whatever is, there is connected to subprime, and the rest of the portfolio that to a large extent has not been affected by the subprime crisis.

You'll find that the methodological criteria. It's all mark-to-market whatever is possible to mark-to-market is everything, obviously, according to the international accounting standards. Where there is not a market, there is a mark-to-model. But in that case further external appraisals, evaluations have been asked in order to be sure that what we have is exactly the right evaluation.

This is the total picture, subprime is minus 49. We are short in the sense – and you'll get the figures – that our short positions are higher than the long positions. So we are against subprime. The contagion net exposure is 500 million and we will tell you how we have devaluated that. The monoline risks is 61 million. And then we have the portfolio that is not affected, is not very indirectly by the subprime risk and we will give you all these details. If we take the portfolio, all, everything is investment grade. If we take the portfolio from the vintage point of view, 42% is before 2005, 30% is 2005 and then a little part of it is after that.

Some of these assets come from far away in the past decisions, when we decided we had a lot of free capital to put some of this money in these products with the idea, and we confirm it to keep them until maturity. So most of these products are not liquid, but it was like that. Some of them were inherited by Comet and we decided to wait for them to get to maturity.

So sometimes when you want to apply market prices to such situations, you have extravagant figures, and we obviously applied the market prices. But this portfolio is kept and will be kept until maturity. We don't have to sell, we don't have any push and any need to sell. So as I said before, some of the devaluations will be – will become capital gains at the beginning – at the end, sorry.

Only 11% of the portfolio is US residential linked. This is an example of the kind of figures that you will get with the details afterwards. Take the subprime, long position nominal value, face value 269, short position 220, net position 49. At the end of September, you might remember, 11. That was the situation at the end of September. Then if you take the write-downs or the write-backs, this long position had lost – not realized – but let's say had lost 195. The short position, obviously, had increased in value and the net effect of write-downs and write-backs is 96. So we have today an exposure of 73 and an edging situation, a short position of 122. So we are short of subprime.

The area of contagion, you will find each category, the multi-sector CDOs, the Alt-A, the TruPS, the Prime CMO. You find in the black box – in the blue box the exposure, the short position we have, the P&L effect we paid during the year, and then you find exactly the content in terms of collateral. What kind of assets is there? What kind of rating are these assets? What kind of attachment point we have? You know that attachment point means the amount until which you don't lose even if the vehicle loses.

So, for example, in this case attachment point of 30% it means that the first 30% of loss does not belong to us, and then we have taken another 14% devaluation to make sure that losses will not get to us. And the kind of criteria have been used to evaluate, etcetera, etcetera. So for each category you have the detail. Monoline, as I said, is a small position. You have all the – some of the detail in this page and other details in the appendices.

Than you have the rest of the portfolio. And in the rest of the portfolio, again, you have the description of the CDOs or the ABS, and the kind – the vintage, the attachment point, the content and the reasons why we have made some write-downs or some write-offs. I will not go through all of them, but you have them in your document.
Now we are at page 27, 27 is income from insurance business, more or less in line despite bad performances of the market in the second semester, more or less the same performance in the two years.

Cost, operating costs has always been and will remain one of our strength. We have a good cost control. We have also some contingency in the case some revenue growth has to be balanced in our result. As you know, it's a minus, it's minus also for personnel, despite we don't have yet the exits in – or very small part of the assets in 2007. Let's say, everything is really under control and a little bit better than the Business Plan.

Cost of risk – provision for risks and charges. This growth of the risks and charges comes from the Parmalat and the Finmek case. I mean, that's what I described before, most of it. In terms of net adjustments to loans is more or less what we had in mind, and a good part of the growth comes from the extraordinary decisions that we took for marketing reasons, the one I mentioned before at the beginning of the year. And here we have the Parmalat case, so something that I've already said.

Total bad assets, non-performing loans, if you put all of them together and if we compare the total amount on non-performing loans at the end of 2007 and at the end of 2006, you see that the decrease is significant, because with an increase of 10% of loan value you could have expected a growth in the total amount of net non-performing loans. But that was not the case.

Capital ratios, we have 6.2, at the end of the year is 5.9 without considering the sale of the branches we had done at the beginning of the year. As we said, we will remain between 6 and 6.5% during the period of the Business Plan, and then at the end we will decide. But our attitude is to bring this level down to 6%.

An important point is that in this figure we already have the special dividends and we have a good part of the Carifirenze acquisition. These two points are important, because we realized that the possible disposals of non-core assets, we said in the Business Plan 3/4 billion, it will be certainly higher than that. And that will give us the possibility to finance, if any, to finance new acquisitions just by selling assets of ours.

The subdivision of the result by business unit division, you have obviously all the details in the appendices. But you know that all the divisions without exception is contributing in a very positive way to the results and to the improvement we had in 2007.

We are now at page 33 and it's the integration chapter. We had the first chapter the results, the second chapter is integration, and the third one is the growth drivers. Integration is going very well. I made just a shortlist of the many things that have been done without any real trouble during 2007. And when you have two banks like ours merging and then becoming one and performing all this tasks at the same time, generally you get a level of disarray that blocks the growth, that creates a lot of trouble. That was not the case and that's thanks to the quality and the commitment and the generosity of our people and the quality of our top team of managers.

We changed everything at the headquarters. We changed everything in the field. All the management systems have been unified. Union agreements, we made more than 100 trade union agreements during the year. And we've gone through these difficult phase together with all the trade unions that represent our employees in a very responsible and effective way.

We have chosen the IT system and we were now migrating all the Group to the new system. We have performed all the intra group mergers, the product companies, the international banks in Eastern Europe, the specialized banks, everything has been done, has been at least prepared and partially implemented during 2007. And then, the back-office projects that is underway. This is one of the evidence of the fact that we are in advance. We said the Group will be on the new IT system by the end of 2008, actually we will get to that result by July.

Second area of advance is that we've done what we said in terms of reduction of people and we have – let me use the word reserve – that is we have 2,000 people more that might be available to leave, and that will be part of the discussion we will have with the trade unions. That for sure having the potential availability of 2,000 people is an opportunity, as you can understand.

In terms of shareholding rationalizations, we will do more than what we had in the Business Plan and we are very much ahead of schedule. Cost synergies, only a very small part of them were due in 2007. The good part will be in 2008, but especially in 2009.

Third chapter, the drivers for growth. These are things that could not be developed during the integration and the first period, where the priority was putting together the two banks. They have been launched during the year and they are now being implemented. They will start giving their results during the next months. They will have to be at full speed at the end of the year.

This is only to repeat the point that despite the integration we are growing. This is an important point. We are adding 5,000 people to the front end, to the sales force, and that will be done during – mostly during 2008, because this year we are creating 3,000 new account managers. But they will start being effective only by the end of the year.

This is Banca dei Territori with a very large number of projects, more than projects, changes underway. Let me just go through the pages. Page 43 is to say that the new organization on modeling the field has been defined and implemented throughout Italy. Page 44, the rationalization of products that is a massive effort, is underway. The simplification of the contract is – will be mostly done during 2008, and we have decided in a number of case to concentrate a very wide product range in just one product. A very large number of new products have been launched, most of them only in the last few weeks and months. So we will get the results during the coming months.

Page 45, the marketing and sales instruments. We have to create a new CRM, new management system, a new territorial presence coverage. I mean, all the systems are now developed, are being distributed – are being distributed in the network, and they will certainly give a strong support to the growth. Intesa Sanpaolo Private Banking is a well kept secret. We have one of the largest private banks in the country, and probably in Europe, because it's already 82 billion worth of assets and we will clearly go well beyond the 100 billion after the full integration will take place. It's a leader in its industry.

Mediocredito Italiano is another very important instrument. It has been created, the new Mediocredito Italiano, only in the last weeks, is the area – is the center of competence for medium and long-term loans for leasing, for whatever, is project finance for SMEs. It works obviously together with Banca IMI that is the main area of competence in investment banking. But it concentrates on the needs of SMEs. That, as you know, in Italy is a very important part of our market.

Banca Prossima, Banca Prossima is a unique instrument of our Group. I mean, it's a bank totally devoted to social enterprises and to not for profit initiatives. It's a very large part of our society, not only economy, we are talking about tens of thousands of organizations, tens of billions of revenues, hundreds of thousands, millions, actually millions of people involved in the non-profit organizations. We have quite a long experience in this area. We decided to create a dedicated bank.

The drivers for growth in the Corporate & Investment banking area, that's another leadership position of the Group. We have been – they have been able to complete the total integration of the corporate relationship. The new Banca IMI is effective from October 2007. The leader in most of the markets where they operate; equity capital market, debt capital market, IPOs. I mean, we're talking about a very strong organization. We are developing a strong position in International Trade Services.

We have a unique – let me – I tend to stress this point not because I want to sell, but because when I say it's unique, like Banca Prossima. Merchant Banking, the kind of people, the kind of skills we have in these unit in our Group are really unique. I mean, the kind of deals we have done in the last few years. The kind of investments and divestments we have done in the last few years have been a very strong contributor to our results, and have proved to be a competitive advantage, because sometimes putting credit, putting loans is not enough. You have to be part also of the equity part on a temporary basis, then you have to divest. But in a number of cases, some restructuring, some generation passes, some big merger, some international project have been – have become possible because of this capability of ours to be also equity provider, not only financing provider. Factoring is another area of leadership we've in the country.

This is Banca IMI. These are two elements of – that give the leading position we have in equity capital market and in most debt capital markets in our country. Banca Infrastrutture Innovazione e Sviluppo, we decided to have a dedicated vehicle to public finance. Public finance in our country is a growing area. We have to build infrastructures. We have to optimize the financing of the healthcare system. We have to finance whatever is public and collaboration between public and private. This bank is – has become the leading bank in public finance in Italy and we aspect quite a growth from them.

These are the International Subsidiary Banks. 2008, we'll benefit from a number of investments. We are opening 200 branches. We are completing the merger between the banks we have in different countries. We have created a network of centers of excellence in a number of areas that are servicing all our 10 banks in the 10 countries. And we recently bought, whereby we are completing, finalizing the purchase of a bank in Ukraine. Ukraine was one of the targets of the Business Plan. We almost succeeded in doing something some months ago, but then we failed. Then we found a very interesting opportunity because we didn't want to buy assets or to buy equity in Ukraine. And we wanted to buy a network of branches and we found a network of 600 branches for something in around of $500 million, so is a bit less than 1 million per branch and that will become quite an important, quite an effective platform for our development in that interesting country.
Here we have some of the details of all our banks in Eastern and Central Europe, and in Egypt. We will not go through these details. These last – probably the last point that is a very important one.

Asset under management, today we are suffering from the market crisis, but asset under management is the single largest opportunity of ours, I said it before. If we take the financial assets of our customers page 57, its 1 trillion, because if you put together the deposits, the asset under administration and the asset under management, you get to 1 trillion. Our customers have with us 1 trillion worth of assets. That's why we believe that just a small percentage of these assets will be certainly moved to asset under management products. And if you make your estimate – I will not – but even if you take 5 to 10% and you apply market commissions, you will see why we have in mind the results we have for 2009.

Obviously we have to do something that is not easy. That's why we will probably have to add skills, competencies. We are looking for some boutique. We have looked at a number of opportunities. We are not going to buy anything in the short term because of the market situation. We will not buy anything big anyhow. But this is an area where the goldmine is very interesting. We have to be able to exploit it.

We already have good people, but we have to add brands, competencies, a network that today we don't have. But this become – this will become one area of excellence. The new management we have on board is the right one. Nextra joined the Group at the beginning of the year. So we are just integrating the two asset management companies. It will take a couple of months. But here we have a strong platform for growth.

Last page, just to remember that 2007 was the year of the integration. 2008 has to be the year of the completion of the growth drivers. 2009 has to be the new cruise – the year of the new speed. We will do them. We will do what we have in mind. The kind of investments we are making in capital – in the human capital, more 1.5 million base of trading is a massive investment. We will invest in innovation more than 3 billion in the three years and we have not stopped. We have not slowed it down, because we believe that if you have a long-term perspective, that's the way to create value for your shareholders. And so we confirm all the targets, all the financial targets of the Group.

Conclusions, 2007 has been a difficult year, but a good year. Growth in line, cost better than expected, risk in line, drivers being created for new growth. We have a number of strength that we will try to exploit as well as possible. The main one, let me tell you, is our cohesiveness in terms of tough team is the kind of people, the 100,000 people we have in the Group and their commitment. I want formally, officially thank them because if we got to the results we are showing today is because of their overall commitment to our Business Plan.

Last point, I will remain here just to make it simple. I mean, I had prepared a very elaborated phrase to say that my commitment in the future, et cetera. If there are rumors about my leaving this Group, they are not true, full stop. Now the questions.
Good afternoon, sir. Luigi Tramontana from Banca Akros. Just a clarification on...
I'm just looking – I am just coming here because I have someone else. Yes, please.

Just a clarification on page 20 about the composition of the portfolio relating to RMBS, CMBS, CDOs, CLOs, et cetera. What's the value of this portfolio? Is it the sum of the amount we have above or something different? And the second question is about Telecom Italia, your exposure there. Can you elaborate a little bit about your exposure in terms of equity, in terms of loans? What's your view in terms of valuation? Will you do any mark-to-market on your equity exposure? Thank you.

First question. The figures you have on the left top side of the page are the net exposure we have in the different categories. How we got to the net exposures is explained in the following pages and in the appendices. Because we start with the nominal value, the write-downs or write-off is according to the fiscal situations. And then we get to the net exposure that is what you have there, if that was the question. The content of each item is also explained in the pages. Is that enough for the first question?
